newsitem.title: AZERBAIJAN: AIOC signs pipeline deal with Azeri/Turkey venture.
newsitem.headline: AIOC signs pipeline deal with Azeri/Turkey venture.

text.p: The Azerbaijan International Operating Company (AIOC) oil consortium signed a $20 million deal on Friday with Azeri-Turkish joint venture TEKFEN/AZFEN for the partial refurbishment of an oil pipeline that will transport AIOC output to world markets.

The $8-billion consortium said in a press release that it signed the contract with a joint venture between Azerbaijan's State oil company SOCAR and Turkey's Tekfen Inshaat ve Tesisat A.S. SOCAR has a 60 percent share and the Turkish firm 40 percent.
TEKFEN/AZFEN won a tender held between international firms to rehabilitate a 47-km (27 mile) stretch of the line in northern Azerbaijan.
Other firms are involved in refurbishing other parts of the route, and total reconstruction costs are put at $315 million.
The pipeline will be capable of carrying 115,000 barrels per day (bpd) of crude from near Baku to the Georgian Black Sea outlet of Supsa upon its completiton in 1998.
It is one of two existing routes AIOC intends to use to export so-called "early oil" from its fields. The second goes from Baku to the Russian port of Novorossiisk and crosses war-ravaged Chechnya.

Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin and Chechen leader Aslan Maskhadov signed a memorandum on Friday which included an agreement on transporting oil across the breakaway region's territory, Itar-Tass news agency said.

The AIOC is also making recommendations to the Azeri government on alternatives for building a new route to be used to handle the bulk of output from the project, which is expected to peak at 700-800,000 bpd by 2007-10.
The AIOC consortium is led by British Petroleum and Norway's Statoil (Den norske stats oljeselskap).
SOCAR has a 10 percent stake in the consortium, and the Azeri government is to receive over 70 percent of the proceeds over its 30-year lifespan.
